page.title: 03Farming around Stratton
page.content: Wrackleford Estate covers the sout-west facing chalk hillside running to the River Frome. Two dairies are the main enterprise because of the good grass conditions, but barley and wheat are also grown for animal feed and sometimes malting. Strip cultivation was in operation until very late in the nineteenth century. The fields are now much larger; many hedges have been removed to accomodate much larger machinery. Tractors, fuel tanks and machinery appropriate for every job are seen in the sheds and barns scattered from Grimstone to Wrackleford. Stratton Farm is the centre for calf-rearing, pesticide stores, fertilisers and straw, now stored in rolls for bedding. Pheasants are reared for several shoots.
